repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
These are the `ESC[1~` and `ESC[4~` keys that PuTTY sends for Home/End; they don't match what the 'xterm' terminfo has, so libtermkeys reports them as the original VT220 names.

I was hesitant to just permanently map them to K_HOME/K_END here, but having Neovim recognize them as their own keys will at the very least allow users to `:imap <Find> <Home>` or something along those lines.

(Of course, configuring PuTTY to set TERM=putty[-256color] would *in theory* be the preferred solution, but in practice it causes other problems due to other features missing from the 'putty' terminfo, as well as older systems that lack the terminfo entirely. Having Neovim recognize the keys is the least bad workaround.)

comment_data.body: Why are these placed in the middle of keypad keys? I think these should be placed around `K_HELP`. And why are they named `K_KFIND` and `K_KSELECT` instead of `K_FIND` and `K_SELECT`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -373,6 +373,9 @@ enum key_extra {
 #define K_KPAGEDOWN     TERMCAP2KEY('K', '5')   // keypad pagedown (lower R.)
 #define K_KORIGIN       TERMCAP2KEY('K', '2')   // keypad center
 
+#define K_KFIND         TERMCAP2KEY('@', '0')   // DEC keys ("Home" and "End"
+#define K_KSELECT       TERMCAP2KEY('*', '6')   // in PuTTY with TERM=xterm)
+

@@ -283,6 +283,9 @@ static const struct key_name_entry {
   { K_KORIGIN,         "kOrigin" },
   { K_KORIGIN,         "KP5" },
 
+  { K_KFIND,           "Find" },        // "Home" and "End" in
+  { K_KSELECT,         "Select" },      // PuTTY with TERM=xterm
+

comment_data.body:
> Why are these placed in the middle of keypad keys?

I placed them there because that's where K_HOME and K_END are also defined, even though they're not keypad keys either. I'll move them next to K_HELP.

> And why are they named K_KFIND and K_KSELECT instead of K_FIND and K_SELECT?

`K_SELECT` is already in use (by mouse-related things it seems) and I could not decide what other name to choose. Renaming the existing K_SELECT seemed too invasive so I thought "I'll name it K_KSELECT until someone suggests better names".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -373,6 +373,9 @@ enum key_extra {
 #define K_KPAGEDOWN     TERMCAP2KEY('K', '5')   // keypad pagedown (lower R.)
 #define K_KORIGIN       TERMCAP2KEY('K', '2')   // keypad center
 
+#define K_KFIND         TERMCAP2KEY('@', '0')   // DEC keys ("Home" and "End"
+#define K_KSELECT       TERMCAP2KEY('*', '6')   // in PuTTY with TERM=xterm)
+

comment_data.body: Oh, then I think `K_KFIND` and `K_KSELECT` are fine.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -373,6 +373,9 @@ enum key_extra {
 #define K_KPAGEDOWN     TERMCAP2KEY('K', '5')   // keypad pagedown (lower R.)
 #define K_KORIGIN       TERMCAP2KEY('K', '2')   // keypad center
 
+#define K_KFIND         TERMCAP2KEY('@', '0')   // DEC keys ("Home" and "End"
+#define K_KSELECT       TERMCAP2KEY('*', '6')   // in PuTTY with TERM=xterm)
+

comment_regular_data.body:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2204 would be an alternative I guess, then you could `:set <F32>=^[...` and map to `<F32>` instead of `<Find>`. However the [latest comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2204#issuecomment-1890988865) there points out that this is not great for maintaining a config.

> I was hesitant to just permanently map them to K_HOME/K_END here

Is that because of the risk of "false positives"?

I can't think of any reason _not_ add more TERMCAP2KEY mappings, except that the `<Find>` and `<Select>` keycodes are a bit random, and Vim doesn't have them. Do you have a reference for the "DEC keys"?

Last time we added keycodes: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/d13803f64fc5607c6319087240e35a8b86082f64

If others don't have objections, this would need docs and a [test](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/5e6240ffc24e55ecf7721fd9dc3f33c6f178be8c/test/functional/ui/input_spec.lua#L16).

> except that the `<Find>` and `<Select>` keycodes are a bit random

I wasn't the one who made them up. Those are the existing key names that Neovim *already* receives via libtermkey in this situation, as I've found out via strace between the two nvim processes – I literally saw the strings `<Find>` and `<Select>` being exchanged through the RPC from Neovim's "frontend" process to the "backend" process.

But currently Neovim completely ignores them and doesn't allow mapping them to anything else; the patch just makes that possible.

> Do you have a reference for the "DEC keys"?

I didn't dig *very* deep into why libtermkey chose those names, but my assumption is that they're named after the [DEC LK201 keyboard](https://deskthority.net/wiki/DEC_LK201) that the physical VT220 used. Looking at photos online, it had 'Find' as key 1 and 'Select' as key 4 in roughly the same area where we now have Ins/Home/Del/End, so it seems to exactly fit the ESC[1~ and ESC[4~ key sequences.

[![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/31021/6c9353d8-c0e8-418a-883b-d8ea63c81969)](https://deskthority.net/wiki/File:LK201AA_cursor.jpg)

I'm guessing PuTTY re-purposes ESC[1~ (Find) and ESC[4~ (Select) for Home/End just to have them nicely fit in with the rest (Ins/Del and PgUp/PgDn).

> Is that because of the risk of "false positives"?

False positives, yes, and also – because I'm only adding existing key names that technically already have a their own meaning (even if obsolete), it didn't feel quite right to permanently map them to entirely different keys at Nvim level. This is my first patch so I was aiming for the "least invasive" option.

(I'm actually not sure how to map them to Home/End directly – I think I could change the table in keycodes.c to `{ K_HOME, "Find" }`, but I think the key would still be called "`<Find>`" regardless?)
@grawity thanks, that is great info to add to the commit message!

> Last time we added keycodes: [d13803f](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/d13803f64fc5607c6319087240e35a8b86082f64)

~Okay, so looking at this, I assume I could add `case K_FIND: ... return VTERM_KEY_HOME` in terminal.c to permanently?~ (That didn't work.)

After thinking more about it, false positives are probably unlikely, as tmux also sends the same key sequences when translating Home/End (and PC keyboards do not have Find/Select keys anyway).

I moved the keycode definitions next to K_HELP and renamed K_KFIND to K_FIND, but still not sure what better name to use instead of K_KSELECT (as K_SELECT is already taken).

@grawity You're right - I picked the names to match what the original DEC keyboard and terminals would do there. A fair number of modern terminals specifically use "CSI H" and "CSI F" as encodings for the `<Home>` and `<End>` keys, rather than functions 1 and 4.
I'm not really familiar with how neovim uses libvterm or not, and therefore what the logic of the TERMCAP2KEY function is doing here, so I'm not sure how much further I could help here.
@grawity I missed this somehow. Please rebase then I'll merge it.

title: Recognize <Find> and <Select> key codes
